parts: What cas tags can I add to obsidian for exported chatgpt convos

In Obsidian, **CAS (Contextual Action System)** tags aren't a built-in concept, but if you're referring to a tagging system to help organize ChatGPT conversations using **tags that support Context, Action, and Status**, then you're essentially building a **self-managed system of structured metadata tags.**

Here‚Äôs a great starting set of **CAS-style tags** you can use for exported ChatGPT convos:

---

### üß† CONTEXT Tags (`#context/...`)
Describe what the conversation was about.

- `#context/ai-convo`
- `#context/relationship`
- `#context/mental-health`
- `#context/technical-support`
- `#context/astrology`
- `#context/symbol-decoding`
- `#context/spirituality`
- `#context/scripting`
- `#context/termux`
- `#context/self-reflection`
- `#context/dream`
- `#context/entity-contact`
- `#context/journal`

---

### üéØ ACTION Tags (`#action/...`)
Capture what you *need to do*, or what the convo prompted.

- `#action/to-review`
- `#action/to-implement`
- `#action/to-research`
- `#action/to-summarize`
- `#action/to-ask-later`
- `#action/to-connect`
- `#action/to-extract-insight`
- `#action/make-code-snippet`
- `#action/make-poem`
- `#action/use-in-ritual`
- `#action/add-to-database`
- `#action/visualize`
- `#action/spiritbox-prompt`

---

### üìç STATUS Tags (`#status/...`)
Track what‚Äôs been done or still pending.

- `#status/done`
- `#status/in-progress`
- `#status/draft`
- `#status/archived`
- `#status/high-priority`
- `#status/integration-pending`
- `#status/sent-to-model`
- `#status/follow-up-needed`

---

### üß© OPTIONAL EXTRA
Under file property it says css tags and then asks what for the css tags

Ah! You're referring to **frontmatter properties** in Obsidian‚Äôs YAML block at the top of a note‚Äîspecifically the `css-classes` or possibly a custom field like `css tags`. Here's a breakdown so you can use it correctly:

---

### ‚úÖ What You‚Äôre Seeing

In the frontmatter block at the top of your note:

```yaml
---
title: Exported Chat
date: 2025-06-12
css-classes: [ai-convo, action-review]
tags: [#context/ai-convo, #action/to-review]
---
```

- `css-classes`: This lets you apply custom **CSS styles** to the entire note based on class names you define.
- `tags`: These are just searchable metadata for filtering, but **not styled** unless you add CSS for them.
- If you're seeing a field like `css tags`, it's either a typo or a plugin-defined/custom frontmatter field.

---

### üßô What to Put in `css-classes`

You should use the **plain name** of your custom class (no `#`, no slashes):

Example:

```yaml
css-classes: [context-ai-convo, action-review, status-done]
```

Then in your CSS snippet (`cas-tags.css`), you'd define:

```css
/* Whole-note background styling by css-classes */
.markdown-preview-view.context-ai-convo {
  background-color: #1a202c; /* dark blue */
  color: #edf2f7;
}

.markdown-preview-view.action-review {
  border-left: 5px solid #38a169;
  padding-left: 10px;
}

.markdown-preview-view.status-done {
  opacity: 0.85;
}
```

This will **style the entire note** depending on what classes you add to `css-classes`.

---

### üí° TL;DR ‚Äî What to Put for "css tags" Field?

If it‚Äôs asking "what to put for `css tags`", you likely want to:

- Rename that to `css-classes`
- Use values like:
  ```yaml
  css-classes: [context-symbolic, action-reflect, status-integration-pending]
  ```

Let me know if you want a ready-made snippet file (`cas-tags.css`) to go with your setup‚ÄîI'll write it custom to your tag categories.
